title: Google Cloud to Announce 10-Year Deal With Dun & Bradstreet; The two companies also plan to co-develop software and services around supply-chain visibility and other business issues
text:
"Between Google and Dun & Bradstreet, we have the data, the technology and the position in the marketplace," said Kevin Coop, president of North America for Dun & Bradstreet.

Other terms of the deal weren't disclosed.

As part of the partnership, Dun & Bradstreet will provide its repository of business data to Google Cloud's Supply Chain Twin, a technology that offers digital representations of physical supply chains.

Kirsten Kliphouse, president of North America for Google Cloud, said the partnership would allow it to offer deeper insights into issues like supply chain disruptions. "Their data really lights up our supply-chain current initiative," she said.

Thomas Kurian, chief executive of Google, said in a statement, "Dun & Bradstreet's reputation for business data and delivering innovative capabilities, combined with our leading analytics, artificial intelligence and machine-learning technologies, will bring new opportunities to our mutual customers."

Shipping bottlenecks have raised the profile of technologies that might ease those snarls. And demand is on the rise for visibility technology, said Koray Kose, a senior director analyst in Gartner Inc.'s supply-chain sourcing and procurement team.

In a Gartner survey last year, 73% of companies said they were either on the hunt for or in the process of putting in place supply-chain visibility tech. "That's a huge frenzy," Mr. Kose said.

The logistics crunch of the last year has also led to an explosion in investment. Supply-chain technology startups raised $24.3 billion in venture funding in the first three quarters of 2021, 58% more than the full-year total for 2020, according to analytics firm PitchBook Data Inc.

Google's Dun & Bradstreet deal is the latest in a series from the Alphabet Inc. unit as it works to increase its cloud market share against competitors Amazon.com Inc. and Microsoft Corp.

Earlier this month, Google Cloud said it would provide cloud-computing services to Cleveland-based regional bank KeyBank National Association, a subsidiary of KeyCorp. In November, Google said it had invested $1 billion in CME Group Inc. and struck a deal that would move the exchange's core trading systems to Google Cloud.

Write to Isabelle Bousquette at Isabelle.Bousquette@wsj.com

Google Cloud to Announce 10-Year Deal With Dun & Bradstreet
